articles.headline: Amazon Union Loses Vote at Second Staten Island Warehouse
articles.snippet: The results were a setback for the upstart Amazon Labor Union, which won a landmark victory last month at a larger Amazon warehouse nearby.
articles.abstract: The results were a setback for the upstart Amazon Labor Union, which won a landmark victory last month at a larger Amazon warehouse nearby.
articles.lead_paragraph: The growing labor organizing efforts at Amazon were dealt a blow on Monday when workers voted by a wide margin to reject joining a union at a warehouse on Staten Island, just weeks after the union won a landmark victory at a larger facility nearby.
articles.byline: By Karen Weise, Noam Scheiber and Coral Murphy Marcos

articles.headline: Painful Stories Emerge From Mariupol, While Combat Rages to the East
articles.snippet: With its forces making only slow progress and enduring heavy losses, Russia now plans to annex eastern parts of Ukraine after a sham election, the U.S. says.
articles.abstract: With its forces making only slow progress and enduring heavy losses, Russia now plans to annex eastern parts of Ukraine after a sham election, the U.S. says.
articles.lead_paragraph: ZAPORIZHZHIA, Ukraine — Ukrainian civilians evacuated from the ruined city of Mariupol carried with them fresh accounts of survival and terror on Monday as Western nations worked to turn their increasingly expansive promises of aid into action, preparing billions of dollars in military and economic assistance, an oil embargo and other once-unthinkable steps.
articles.byline: By Michael Schwirtz and Michael Levenson

articles.headline: As Feinstein Declines, Democrats Struggle to Manage an Open Secret
articles.snippet: Democrats have quietly accepted the California senator’s memory issues as the status quo, even as her inner circle frets that the spectacle of her difficulties on the job could tarnish her legacy.
articles.abstract: Democrats have quietly accepted the California senator’s memory issues as the status quo, even as her inner circle frets that the spectacle of her difficulties on the job could tarnish her legacy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — She was once pressed to run for governor of California by President Bill Clinton. She was considered as a running mate to former Vice President Walter F. Mondale. And after the bitter 2008 Democratic primary, it was in her living room that former Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton met to make peace.

articles.headline: The Tale of a Crypto Executive Who Wasn’t Who He Said He Was
articles.snippet: The chief operating officer of ZenLedger, a software company, boasted of work for Goldman Sachs and Larry King. Did anyone check to see if it was true?
articles.abstract: The chief operating officer of ZenLedger, a software company, boasted of work for Goldman Sachs and Larry King. Did anyone check to see if it was true?
articles.lead_paragraph: When ZenLedger put out word of a deal in March for the Internal Revenue Service to keep using its software, Dan Hannum said he was “thrilled.” It was a big moment for the company, which has the backing of Mark Cuban and other investors as it aims to be a kind of TurboTax for crypto enthusiasts.

articles.headline: ‘I Don’t Really Have a Business Plan’: How Elon Musk Wings It
articles.snippet: To a degree unseen in any other mogul, the world’s richest man acts on impulse and the belief that he is absolutely right.
articles.abstract: To a degree unseen in any other mogul, the world’s richest man acts on impulse and the belief that he is absolutely right.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Twitter negotiated a sale to Elon Musk last month, the social media company pulled out a corporate takeover playbook.
articles.byline: By Ryan Mac, Cade Metz and Kate Conger

articles.headline: The Era of Cheap and Plenty May Be Ending
articles.snippet: Supplies of goods are coming up short in the pandemic, and prices have jumped. Some economists warn that the changes could linger.
articles.abstract: Supplies of goods are coming up short in the pandemic, and prices have jumped. Some economists warn that the changes could linger.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the past three decades, companies and consumers benefited from cross-border connections that kept a steady supply of electronics, clothes, toys and other goods so abundant it helped prices stay low.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek and Ana Swanson

articles.headline: Get Ready for Another Energy Price Spike: High Electric Bills
articles.snippet: Rates have jumped because of a surge in natural gas prices and could keep rising rapidly for years as utilities invest in electric grids.
articles.abstract: Rates have jumped because of a surge in natural gas prices and could keep rising rapidly for years as utilities invest in electric grids.
articles.lead_paragraph: Already frustrated and angry about high gasoline prices, many Americans are being hit by rapidly rising electricity bills, compounding inflation’s financial toll on people and businesses.

articles.headline: Russia Could Sell More Energy to Asia, but Has to Slash Prices
articles.snippet: Russia wants to sell more oil and coal to China and India, but Western sanctions may make that hard unless Russia offers deep discounts on the price.
articles.abstract: Russia wants to sell more oil and coal to China and India, but Western sanctions may make that hard unless Russia offers deep discounts on the price.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Last year, the Grand Aniva, a Russian tanker with four spherical tanks for holding ultracold liquefied natural gas, sailed back and forth between a gas field in eastern Russia and depots in Japan and Taiwan. But two days after Russia invaded Ukraine, the ship switched routes, sailing to China instead.

articles.headline: Evacuees From Mariupol’s Steel Plant Tell of Horrors and Survival
articles.snippet: Nearly 130 people reached relative safety after sheltering for weeks in dark bunkers under the Azovstal plant, under constant bombardment, with dwindling food.
articles.abstract: Nearly 130 people reached relative safety after sheltering for weeks in dark bunkers under the Azovstal plant, under constant bombardment, with dwindling food.
articles.lead_paragraph: ZAPORIZHZHIA, Ukraine — Some flashed bright smiles and others bent over in heaving sobs, sharing the end of their hellish subterranean ordeal. Here, at last, were ordinary things they thought they might not live to see again: sunlight, enough food and escape from incessant Russian shelling.

articles.headline: Inside Politico’s Historic Scoop
articles.snippet: The publication knew it was onto something big. But first, its leaders had to host a prominent Washington event and say nothing.
articles.abstract: The publication knew it was onto something big. But first, its leaders had to host a prominent Washington event and say nothing.
articles.lead_paragraph: Politico’s top editors and executives spent Sunday morning sipping Bloody Marys and nibbling bite-size waffles and wienerschnitzel as they chatted with top Washington officials, including Secretary of State Antony Blinken and Jen Psaki, the White House press secretary, at an annual brunch hosted at the opulent Georgetown home of Robert Allbritton, a Politico founder.
articles.byline: By Benjamin Mullin and Katie Robertson

articles.headline: Russia’s War Has Been Brutal, but Putin Has Shown Some Restraint. Why?
articles.snippet: Western officials are debating the Kremlin’s calculations in not trying harder to halt weapons shipments in Ukraine. Analysts wonder whether a bigger mobilization by Moscow is on the horizon.
articles.abstract: Western officials are debating the Kremlin’s calculations in not trying harder to halt weapons shipments in Ukraine. Analysts wonder whether a bigger mobilization by Moscow is on the horizon.
articles.lead_paragraph: Russia’s war against Ukraine has leveled cities, killed tens of thousands of people and forced millions of others from their homes.
articles.byline: By Anton Troianovski and Julian E. Barnes
